pli-tv-bu-vb-pc86:0.2: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc86:0.3: The chapter on offenses entailing confession
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc86:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying in the Sakyan country at Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc86:1.3: had invited the monks who needed a needle-case to ask for one.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc86:1.4: And the monks asked for many needle-cases.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc86:1.5: Those who had small needle-cases asked for large ones,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc86:1.6: and those who had large needle-cases asked for small ones.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc86:1.7: The ivory-worker was so busy making needle-cases for the monks that he was not able to make other goods for sale. He could not make a living for himself, and his wives and children suffered.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc86:1.9: “How can the Sakyan ascetics not have any sense of moderation and ask for many needle-cases?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc86:1.10: This ivory-worker is so busy making needle-cases for them that he’s not able to make other goods for sale. He’s unable to make a living for himself, and his wives and children are suffering.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc86:1.11: The monks heard the complaints of those people,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc86:1.12: and the monks of few desires complained and criticized those monks,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc86:1.13: “How can those monks not have a sense of moderation and ask for many needle-cases?” …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc86:1.14: “Is it true, monks, that some monks do this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc86:1.17: “… How can those foolish men not have a sense of moderation and ask for many needle-cases?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc86:1.18: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc86:1.19: And, monks, this training rule should be recited thus:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc86:1.20: ‘If a monk gets a needle-case made from bone, ivory, or horn, it is to be destroyed, and he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc86:2.1.4: … The monk who has been given the full ordination by a complete Sangha through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc86:2.1.8: elephant tooth is what is meant.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc86:2.1.12: if he makes one or gets one made, then the effort constitutes wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc86:2.1.13: When he obtains it, it is to be destroyed, and he is then to confess an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc86:2.2.1: If he finishes what he began himself, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc86:2.2.2: If he gets others to finish what he began himself, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc86:2.2.3: If he finishes himself what was begun by others, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc86:2.2.4: If he gets others to finish what was begun by others, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc86:2.2.5: If he makes one or gets one made for the benefit of someone else, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc86:2.2.6: If he obtains one that was made by someone else and then uses it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc86:2.3.5: if it is an ointment box;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc86:2.3.6: if it is an ointment stick;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc86:2.3.7: if it is a adze handle;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc86:2.3.8: if it is a water wiper;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc86:2.3.10: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc86:2.3.11: The fourth rule, the training rule on needle-cases, is finished.
